<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp025" view="all">(a) The packing structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> on <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane. (b) The packing structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> on <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) The packing structure of 3 on ab plane. (b) The packing structure of 3 on bc plane.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp030" view="all">(a) A polyhedral view of the zigzag chain constructed from Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. (b) A polyhedral view of the 2D layer in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis. (c) The structure of an individual Cd<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(pimda)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> ring in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. (d) The fold ladder structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Color codes: black balls represent Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands; gray balls represent Cd(II) cations.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) A polyhedral view of the zigzag chain constructed from Cd2+ ions and Hpimda2- ligands. (b) A polyhedral view of the 2D layer in 3 along the a-axis. (c) The structure of an individual Cd8(pimda)4 ring in 3. (d) The fold ladder structure of 3. Color codes: black balls represent Hpimda2- ligands; gray balls represent Cd(II) cations.

</ce:caption>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp005" view="all">Three new complexes [Cd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pimda)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pimda)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>].3.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hpimda)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-propyl-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxy acid, DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-dimethylformamide) have been synthesized under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, respectively. Crystal structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystallographic studies on <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveal that both complexes are six-coordinated, whose geometries can be best described as distorted octahedral. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was synthesized based on that of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. We change the coordination environment of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda during the synthesis process of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> by using organic acid and solvent, accordingly result in different structures ranging from 0D for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to infinite 2D network for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Graphical abstract

Three new complexes [Cd(H2pimda)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O (1), [Zn(H2pimda)2(H2O)2].3.5H2O (2) and [Cd2(Hpimda)2(DMF)2] n  (3) (H3pimda=2-propyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxy acid, DMF= N,N'-dimethylformamide) have been synthesized under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, respectively. Crystal structures of complexes 1-3 were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystallographic studies on 1 and 2 reveal that both complexes are six-coordinated, whose geometries can be best described as distorted octahedral. Complex 3 was synthesized based on that of complexes 1 and 2. We change the coordination environment of H3pimda during the synthesis process of complex 3 by using organic acid and solvent, accordingly result in different structures ranging from 0D for 1 and 2 to infinite 2D network for 3. Complexes 1-3 have blue luminescence at room temperature in the dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) solution, which are potential blue luminescence materials. The blue luminescence of complexes 1-3 is due to π∗→π transitions of intra-ligand.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new complexes [Cd(H2pimda)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O (1), [Zn(H2pimda)2(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O (2) and [Cd2(Hpimda)2(DMF)2] n  (3) (H3pimda=2-propyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxy acid, DMF= N,N'-dimethylformamide) have been synthesized under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, respectively. Crystal structures of complexes 1-3 were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystallographic studies on 1 and 2 reveal that both complexes are six-coordinated, whose geometries can be best described as distorted octahedron. Complex 3 was synthesized based on that of complexes 1 and 2. We change the coordination environment of H3pimda during the synthesis process of complex 3 using organic acid and organic solvent, accordingly, result in different structures ranging from 0D molecule (for 1 and 2) to infinite 2D network (for 3). Complexes 1-3 have blue fluorescent emissions at room temperature in the dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) solution, which indicate they are potential blue luminescence materials. The blue fluorescent emissions of complexes 1-3 are due to the π∗ →π transitions of intra-ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Recently, many novel complexes with unique structures have attracted considerable attention not only due to their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications in materials with luminescent and nonlinear optical properties . The selections of metal source and organic ligands play important parts in the crystal engineering of metal–organic frameworks. Meanwhile, we also should pay more attention to the external factors that may affect the structure of metal–organic complex, such as temperature, pressure and pH value . In previous investigations, imidazole-class ligands were successfully utilized to construct numbers of metal complexes, whose luminescence properties have been studied . H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda has been used to construct Ni(II) and Co(II) complexes which have magnetic properties . The molecular structure of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>. H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda acts as a kind of imidazole carboxylic acid ligand has the following advantages: firstly, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda contains N and O atoms which can coordinate to the metal ions to form metal complexes. Secondly, the NH site of the imidazole ring and the carboxyl group can serve as multiple proton donor and acceptor providing a opportunity to form hydrogen bonds. Finally, to our knowledge, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda exhibits blue-green fluorescence in the solid state when excited at room temperature, which is a good candidate for synthesizing fluorescence materials . Based on above reasons, we choose H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda as the studied candidate. As different anionic environment results in different coordination modes of the ligand, we can vary the anionic environment by organic acid and amine. The NH site of the imidazole cannot coordinate to the metal center when the organic acid was used, which can make the solvent molecule coordinate to the metal center, accordingly, the ligand adopt different coordination modes, and result in structural variation in complexes . In this paper, we report the syntheses, structures and luminescent properties of two new Cd(II) complexes and one Zn(II) complex. The crystal structures of these complexes and the systematic investigation of the effect of organic acid will be represented and discussed. The relevance between the structures and the luminescent properties of the complexes are discussed in detail.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, many novel complexes with unique structures have attracted considerable attention not only due to their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications in materials with luminescent and nonlinear optical properties . The selections of metal source and organic ligands play important parts in the crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks. Meanwhile, we also should pay more attention to the external factors that may affect the structure of metal-organic complex, such as temperature, pressure and pH value . In previous investigations, imidazole-class ligands were successfully utilized to construct numbers of metal complexes, whose luminescence properties have been studied . H3pimda has been used to construct Ni(II) and Co(II) complexes which have magnetic properties . The molecular structure of H3pimda is shown in  . H3pimda acts as a kind of imidazole carboxylic acid ligand has the following advantages: firstly, H3pimda contains N and O atoms which can coordinate to the metal ions to form metal complexes. Secondly, the NH site of the imidazole ring and the carboxyl group can serve as multiple proton donor and acceptor providing a opportunity to form hydrogen bonds. Finally, to our knowledge, H3pimda exhibits blue-green fluorescence in the solid state when excited at room temperature, which is a good candidate for synthesizing fluorescence materials . Based on above reasons, we choose H3pimda as the studied candidate. As different anionic environment results in different coordination modes of the ligand, we can vary the anionic environment by organic acid and amine. The NH site of the imidazole cannot coordinate to the metal center when the organic acid was used, which can make the solvent molecule coordinate to the metal center, accordingly, the ligand adopt different coordination modes, and result in structural variation in complexes . In this paper, we report the syntheses, structures and luminescent properties of two new Cd(II) complexes and one Zn(II) complex. The crystal structures of these complexes and the systematic investigation of the effect of organic acid will be represented and discussed. The relevance between the structures and the luminescent properties of the complexes are discussed in detail.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Reagents and general techniques</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer by KBr pellet in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> range. <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ACF 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz spectrometer. ESI-MS spectra were recorded with Finnigan MATLCQ™ mass spectrometer (USA) with a dual electrospray-ionization source. UV–Vis spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 20 spectrometer. Photoluminescence analyses and luminescence decay curves were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature in the range of 300–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Reagents and general techniques

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer by KBr pellet in the 400-4000cm-1 range. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ACF 400MHz spectrometer. ESI-MS spectra were recorded with Finnigan MATLCQ™ mass spectrometer (USA) with a dual electrospray-ionization source. UV-Vis spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 20 spectrometer. Photoluminescence analyses and luminescence decay curves were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature in the range of 300-800nm.

[Cd2(Hpimda)2(DMF)2] n  (3)

Complex 3 was synthesized by heating a mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (61.6mg, 0.2mmol), H3pimda (198mg, 0.1mmol), benzidine (18.4mg, 0.1mmol), terephthalic acid (16.6mg, 0.1mmol) in mixed solutions of DMF (3mL) and H2O (3mL) at 75°C for 48h. Colorless block crystals of 3 were obtained. Yield: 56.64mg (74%). The products were washed by distilled water and dried in air. Anal. Calc. for 3: C, 34.61; N, 11.01; H, 3.93. Found: C, 34.92; N, 11.35; H, 3.99%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3435 (s), 2965 (m), 1658 (vs), 1571 (vs), 1474 (vs), 1383 (vs), 1269 (s), 1125 (s), 921 (m), 787 (w), 677 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO): δ =13.71 (s, 1H, N-H), 4.35 (t, J =5.0Hz, 2H, -CH 2CH2CH3), 3.45 (m, J =5.6Hz, 2H, -CH2CH 2CH3), 1.05 (t, J =7.0Hz, 3H, -CH2CH2CH 3) ppm. ESI-MS: m/z =572.9 [M-2DMF-COOH]-.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallograghy

Suitable single crystals of three complexes were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected on a Siemens SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ =0. 71073Å), operating at 293±2K. The structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix least squares based on F 2 using the SHELXTL 5.1 software package . The zinc and cadmium atoms were first located, carbon and nitrogen atoms were found in difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms residing in the carbon atoms were located geometrically. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Crystallographic data is given in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">By hydrothermal (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and solvothermal (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) methods, we have obtained three complexes which are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. All complexes were characterized using elemental analysis, <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR, ESI-MS, IR spectroscopy and UV–Vis. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were subject to single crystal X-ray diffraction studies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

By hydrothermal (for 1 and 2) and solvothermal (for 3) methods, we have obtained three complexes which are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. All complexes were characterized using elemental analysis, 1H NMR, ESI-MS, IR spectroscopy and UV-Vis. Complexes 1-3 were subject to single crystal X-ray diffraction studies.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was synthesized based on that of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As different anionic environment causes different coordination modes of the ligand, we change the anionic environment of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda using benzidine and terephthalic acid during the synthesis process of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and we also change the solvent by mixed solutions of DMF and water, which can coordinate to the metal center, accordingly, result in different structures ranging from 0D molecule (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) to infinite 2D network (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 3 was synthesized based on that of complexes 1 and 2. As different anionic environment causes different coordination modes of the ligand, we change the anionic environment of H3pimda using benzidine and terephthalic acid during the synthesis process of complex 3, and we also change the solvent by mixed solutions of DMF and water, which can coordinate to the metal center, accordingly, result in different structures ranging from 0D molecule (for 1 and 2) to infinite 2D network (for 3).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were prepared in good yields (>70%), all complexes are stable in the solid state and in the common solutions such as DMSO, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and DMF in the air conditions. All complexes were characterized by UV–Vis, IR spectroscopy and elemental analyses.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complexes 1-3 were prepared in good yields (>70%), all complexes are stable in the solid state and in the common solutions such as DMSO, CH3CN, CH2Cl2 and DMF in the air conditions. All complexes were characterized by UV-Vis, IR spectroscopy and elemental analyses.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">In the IR spectra of the complexes, the signals in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 1534 and 1391<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (1538 and 1400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda, respectively. The IR spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are similar, which indicates these two complexes may be isostructural, this was further confirmed by the single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The asymmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were observed at ca. 1571<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> as a broad band, and the band of symmetric stretching vibrations was observed at ca. 1383<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, while that of the carboxylate groups of free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda ligand is at ca. 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which indicate the carboxylate groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda coordinate to the metal center  ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the IR spectra of the complexes, the signals in complex 1 at 1534 and 1391cm-1 (1538 and 1400cm-1 for 2) correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups of H3pimda, respectively. The IR spectra of complexes 1 and 2 are similar, which indicates these two complexes may be isostructural, this was further confirmed by the single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The asymmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups in complex 3 were observed at ca. 1571cm-1 as a broad band, and the band of symmetric stretching vibrations was observed at ca. 1383cm-1, while that of the carboxylate groups of free H3pimda ligand is at ca. 1700cm-1, which indicate the carboxylate groups of H3pimda coordinate to the metal center  ().

elements.clean_text:
Description of structures

The crystal structures of complexes 1 and 2 are similar. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveal that both complexes exhibit approximate octahedral geometry and crystallize in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . The molecular structure of 1 consists of one Cd(II) cation, two H2pimda- anion ligands, two coordinated water molecules, and four solvate water molecules ( ). While the asymmetric unit of complex 2 consists of two independent complex molecules, each complex molecule contains one Zn(II) cations, two H2pimda- anion ligands, two coordinated water molecules, as well as three and half solvate water molecules. Complexes 1 and 2 are similar, so we take complex 1 as example to depict the structures of 1 and 2 in detail. Crystallographic data for the three complexes is summarized in  and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The coordination mode of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pimda<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> dianion ligand in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>(a). In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the central Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated, forming a slightly distorted octahedron with CdO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coordination mode; the two deprotonated carboxylate groups from the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pimda<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand provide two donor oxygen atoms, the two imidazolyl rings provide two nitrogen atoms, and two coordinated water molecules provide two oxygen atoms, respectively, to bond to the central ion. Each deprotonated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pimda<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion adopts a bidentate coordination mode providing two sites to bond to the central Cd(II) ion. Two imidazole rings nitrogen atoms chelate to the Cd(II) ion with Cd–N bond lengths of 2.288(4) and 2.309(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, and the N–Cd–N bond angle is 99.8(2)°. All Cd–N and Cd–O bond lengths as well as the bond angles around Cd(II) ion are in the range expected for such coordination complexes ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The coordination mode of H2pimda- dianion ligand in complex 1 is shown in  (a). In complex 1, the central Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated, forming a slightly distorted octahedron with CdO4N2 coordination mode; the two deprotonated carboxylate groups from the H2pimda- ligand provide two donor oxygen atoms, the two imidazolyl rings provide two nitrogen atoms, and two coordinated water molecules provide two oxygen atoms, respectively, to bond to the central ion. Each deprotonated H2pimda- anion adopts a bidentate coordination mode providing two sites to bond to the central Cd(II) ion. Two imidazole rings nitrogen atoms chelate to the Cd(II) ion with Cd-N bond lengths of 2.288(4) and 2.309(4)Å, respectively, and the N-Cd-N bond angle is 99.8(2)°. All Cd-N and Cd-O bond lengths as well as the bond angles around Cd(II) ion are in the range expected for such coordination complexes ().

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the architecture of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a two-dimensional network with monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> consists of two cadmium ions, two Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligands and two DMF molecules, which is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The central Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two imidazole rings nitrogen atoms from two single Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, one carboxyl oxygen atom from a single Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and one oxygen atom from DMF molecule; forming a slightly distorted CdO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> octahedron. Bond lengthes of Cd–O vary from 2.265(4) to 2.534(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Cd–N distances range from 2.227(3) to 2.283(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively (

elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the architecture of 3 is a two-dimensional network with monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of complex 3 consists of two cadmium ions, two Hpimda2- dianion ligands and two DMF molecules, which is shown in  . The central Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two imidazole rings nitrogen atoms from two single Hpimda2- ligands, one carboxyl oxygen atom from a single Hpimda2- ligand and one oxygen atom from DMF molecule; forming a slightly distorted CdO4N2 octahedron. Bond lengthes of Cd-O vary from 2.265(4) to 2.534(3)Å and the Cd-N distances range from 2.227(3) to 2.283(4)Å, respectively ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand has two different coordination modes in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> on <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane and <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane because of the coordination of the DMF molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>(a) and (b)), which are shown in (b) and (c). Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand connect four Cd(II) ion centers in bis-(bridging) bidentate and monodentate modes; both carboxylate groups adopt the bidentate coordination modes, and one oxygen atom of 4-carboxylate group of Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand links two adjacent Cd(II) ions to form a dimer. The nitrogen atoms from Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand bond the metal center and transfer these dimers by connecting to the central Cd(II) atoms to form a zigzag chain as described in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>(a). The propyl groups of Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligands are in trans arrangement mode in the complex, which can reduce the steric hindrance. Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand in <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane acts as a tetradentate ligand in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and connect two Cd(II) ion centers in bis-(bridging) bidentate mode (b); an oxygen atom of 4-carboxylate group of Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and a nitrogen atom of the imidazole ring link to the same Cd(II) ion; an oxygen atom of 5-carboxylate group of Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and a nitrogen atom of imidazole ring simultaneously link to another Cd(II) ion. Then, these chains are further connected into a novel 2D grid by the Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand ((b)). Two adjacent Cd(II) ions forms a dimer through the carboxylate group of Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand, then four adjacent dimers arrange in an individual Cd<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(pimda)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> ring as a secondary building unit ((c)). If consider the Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand as a nod, each Cd(II) ion simultaneously links to three Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligands. Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> dianion ligand has two connection modes, link to four and two Cd(II) ions, respectively, further form a distorted quadrilateral and octagon with (4.8.8) topological structure ((d)). If consider these dimers as nods, these Cd<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(pimda)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> rings are further connected into a fold ladder. Additionally, because of the partial deprotonation of the carboxyl group, there are two intramolecular hydrogen bonds in the asymmetric unit, namely O3–H3⋯O2 (1.656<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, 177.45°) and O7–H7⋯O8 (1.633<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, 177.62°), which make the complex more stable (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). To further understand this 2D structure, the familiar dimeric Cd(II) units can be considered as a node, and the Hpimda<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> dianion ligand is a linker.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Hpimda2- dianion ligand has two different coordination modes in complex 3 on ab plane and bc plane because of the coordination of the DMF molecule ( (a) and (b)), which are shown in (b) and (c). Hpimda2- dianion ligand connect four Cd(II) ion centers in bis-(bridging) bidentate and monodentate modes; both carboxylate groups adopt the bidentate coordination modes, and one oxygen atom of 4-carboxylate group of Hpimda2- dianion ligand links two adjacent Cd(II) ions to form a dimer. The nitrogen atoms from Hpimda2- dianion ligand bond the metal center and transfer these dimers by connecting to the central Cd(II) atoms to form a zigzag chain as described in  (a). The propyl groups of Hpimda2- dianion ligands are in trans arrangement mode in the complex, which can reduce the steric hindrance. Hpimda2- dianion ligand in bc plane acts as a tetradentate ligand in 3 and connect two Cd(II) ion centers in bis-(bridging) bidentate mode (b); an oxygen atom of 4-carboxylate group of Hpimda2- ligand and a nitrogen atom of the imidazole ring link to the same Cd(II) ion; an oxygen atom of 5-carboxylate group of Hpimda2- ligand and a nitrogen atom of imidazole ring simultaneously link to another Cd(II) ion. Then, these chains are further connected into a novel 2D grid by the Hpimda2- dianion ligand ((b)). Two adjacent Cd(II) ions forms a dimer through the carboxylate group of Hpimda2- dianion ligand, then four adjacent dimers arrange in an individual Cd8(pimda)4 ring as a secondary building unit ((c)). If consider the Hpimda2- dianion ligand as a nod, each Cd(II) ion simultaneously links to three Hpimda2- dianion ligands. Hpimda2- dianion ligand has two connection modes, link to four and two Cd(II) ions, respectively, further form a distorted quadrilateral and octagon with (4.8.8) topological structure ((d)). If consider these dimers as nods, these Cd8(pimda)4 rings are further connected into a fold ladder. Additionally, because of the partial deprotonation of the carboxyl group, there are two intramolecular hydrogen bonds in the asymmetric unit, namely O3-H3⋯O2 (1.656Å, 177.45°) and O7-H7⋯O8 (1.633Å, 177.62°), which make the complex more stable ( ). To further understand this 2D structure, the familiar dimeric Cd(II) units can be considered as a node, and the Hpimda- dianion ligand is a linker.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Luminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor> presents the absorption and emission data for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda in DMSO solution and in the solid state at room temperature. Three complexes show two main absorption bands, which are similar to H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda in the UV region. The electronic absorption spectra of complexes show low energy absorption bands at ca. 334–365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda), and higher energy absorption bands at ca. 284–301<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (291<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda), which can be attributed to ligand-centered π<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> transitions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

   presents the absorption and emission data for complexes 1-3 and H3pimda in DMSO solution and in the solid state at room temperature. Three complexes show two main absorption bands, which are similar to H3pimda in the UV region. The electronic absorption spectra of complexes show low energy absorption bands at ca. 334-365nm (340nm for ligand H3pimda), and higher energy absorption bands at ca. 284-301nm (291nm for ligand H3pimda), which can be attributed to ligand-centered π→π∗ transitions .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The luminescent properties of these three metal complexes and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda have been investigated in the solutions of DMSO (). The emission bands of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda are observed at 417, 439<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">sh</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> and 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm under excitation at maximum excitation wavelength of 312<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in solution of DMSO. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has blue fluorescent emissions in DMSO solution (concentration: [M]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≈<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>) at room temperature, with emission bands at 420, 439<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">sh</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> and 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (415, 439<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">sh</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> and 465<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; 415, 438<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">sh</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>, 464<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). For the multiple emission bands of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the main peaks locate at their expected positions compared with the free ligand. The resemblance of the emission spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda ligand in DMSO solution supports that the luminescence emissions of these complexes are due to ligand-centered π<ce:sup loc="post">∗<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:sup>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π transitions. The quantum yields of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda in DMSO solution were determined, with the value of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda is 0.022, while that of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are 0.33, 0.34 and 0.11, respectively. The quantum yields of these complexes are greatly improved compared with free ligand. That because the chelation of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda to the metal center, which increases the rigidity of the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda, and reduces the loss of energy by thermal vibration decay, enhances the ligand-centered π<ce:sup loc="post">∗<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:sup>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π fluorescent emission . Furthermore, the quantum yield of the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is higher than that of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which can be attributed to the heavy atom effect caused by the coordination of the ligand to the heavy Cd(II) center .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The luminescent properties of these three metal complexes and H3pimda have been investigated in the solutions of DMSO (). The emission bands of H3pimda are observed at 417, 439 sh  and 466nm under excitation at maximum excitation wavelength of 312nm in solution of DMSO. Complex 1 has blue fluorescent emissions in DMSO solution (concentration: [M]~10-4) at room temperature, with emission bands at 420, 439 sh  and 466nm (415, 439 sh  and 465nm for complex 2; 415, 438 sh , 464nm for 3). For the multiple emission bands of complexes 1-3, the main peaks locate at their expected positions compared with the free ligand. The resemblance of the emission spectra of complexes 1-3 and the free H3pimda ligand in DMSO solution supports that the luminescence emissions of these complexes are due to ligand-centered π∗ →π transitions. The quantum yields of complexes 1-3 and H3pimda in DMSO solution were determined, with the value of H3pimda is 0.022, while that of complexes 1-3 are 0.33, 0.34 and 0.11, respectively. The quantum yields of these complexes are greatly improved compared with free ligand. That because the chelation of H3pimda to the metal center, which increases the rigidity of the ligand H3pimda, and reduces the loss of energy by thermal vibration decay, enhances the ligand-centered π∗ →π fluorescent emission . Furthermore, the quantum yield of the complex 2 is higher than that of complexes 1 and 3, which can be attributed to the heavy atom effect caused by the coordination of the ligand to the heavy Cd(II) center .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have blue-green fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor> shows the excitation and emission spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as well as the free ligand in the solid state measured at room temperature. The emission bands of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are located at 404 and 460<ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: Complexes 1-3 have blue-green fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.   shows the excitation and emission spectra of complexes 1-3 as well as the free ligand in the solid state measured at room temperature. The emission bands of complex 1 are located at 404 and 460 sh  nm (408, 467 sh  and 507nm for complex 2, 480nm for 3), which is similar to that of free ligand. The fluorescent emissions of complexes 1-3 can be assigned to the intra-ligand π∗ →π transitions. In addition to the steady-state emission, we also performed time-resolved measurements of complexes 1-3. The luminescence decay curves of complexes 1-3 are measured by the time-correlated single photon counting (TCSPC) technique at room temperature. The decay curves are well fitted into a double-exponential function: I 0 = I + A 1exp(-t/τ 1)+ A 2exp(-t/τ 2), I 0 and I are the luminescent intensities when time t = t and t =0, respectively, whereas τ 1 and τ 2 are defined as the luminescent lifetimes (). The fluorescence decay processes of complexes 1-3 all consist of two components, corresponding lifetimes are τ 1 =1.07μs, τ 2 =7.97μs for 1; τ 1 =1.43μs, τ 2 =9.85μs for 2; τ 1 =1.51μs, τ 2 =9.10μs for 3, respectively ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In conclusion, three new metal–organic complexes based on rigid H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda ligand have been successfully synthesised under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, respectively. The structures of the complexes can affect their fluorescence emission features. We found that the luminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are similar because of the similarity of the coordination environment around the metal center. Meanwhile, we use organic acid and amine to change the coordination environment of the ligand, which result in the NH site cannot coordinate to the metal center. Owing to this, the structures of the complexes change from discrete molecule (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) to 2D (structure for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the coordination behaviors of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pimda ligands on <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane and <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane are different because of the coordination of DMF. Their luminescent properties show that they all have potential applications in optoelectronic devices.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, three new metal-organic complexes based on rigid H3pimda ligand have been successfully synthesised under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, respectively. The structures of the complexes can affect their fluorescence emission features. We found that the luminescent properties of 1 and 2 are similar because of the similarity of the coordination environment around the metal center. Meanwhile, we use organic acid and amine to change the coordination environment of the ligand, which result in the NH site cannot coordinate to the metal center. Owing to this, the structures of the complexes change from discrete molecule (for 1 and 2) to 2D (structure for 3). In complex 3, the coordination behaviors of H3pimda ligands on ab plane and bc plane are different because of the coordination of DMF. Their luminescent properties show that they all have potential applications in optoelectronic devices.

Syntheses of complexes

Cd(H2pimda)2(H2O)2⋅(H2O)4 (1) and [Zn(H2pimda)2(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O (2)

A mixture of H3pimda (198mg, 0.1mmol), 3,3',4,4'-biphenyltetracarboxylic acid (33.0mg, 0.1mmol) and Cd(NO3)2 ⋅4H2O (61.6mg, 0.2mmol) were dissolve in H2O (5mL), and stirred for half an hour, then heated in a sealed vial at 75°C for 3days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 23.67mg (77%). The products were washed with distilled water and dried in air. Anal. Calc. for 1: C, 31.25; H, 4.89; N, 9.12. Found: C, 31.65; H, 4.83; N, 9.45%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3433 (s), 2968 (m), 1712 (s), 1534 (vs), 1472 (m), 1391 (s), 1267 (m), 1052 (w), 776(m). 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO): δ =13.73 (s, 1H, N-H), 4.35 (t, J =5.0Hz, 2H, -CH 2CH2CH3), 3.44 (m, J =5.2Hz, 2H, -CH2CH 2CH3), 1.06 (t, J =7.0Hz, 3H, -CH2CH2CH 3) ppm. ESI-MS: m/z =615.0 [M]-, 614.0 [M-H]-, 569.9 [M-COOH]-.

A procedure similar to 1 was followed to prepare 2 except Cd(NO3)2 ⋅4H2O (61.6mg, 0.2mmol) was replaced by Zn(AcO)2 (43.9mg, 0.2mmol). Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 19.97mg (72%). The products were washed by distilled water and dried in air. Anal. Calc. for 2: C, 34.61; H, 5.23; N, 10.09. Found: C, 34.25; H, 5.09; N, 9.92%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3425 (s), 3169 (s), 2967 (m), 1713 (s), 1538 (vs), 1462 (m), 1400 (s), 1277 (m), 774 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO): δ =13.70 (s, 1H, N-H), 2.54 (br s, 2H, -CH 2CH2CH3), 1.46 (br s, 2H, -CH2CH 2CH3), 0.71 (t, J =4.0Hz, 3H, -CH2CH2CH 3) ppm. ESI-MS: m/z 910.8 [2M-H-11H2O]-, 733.9 [2M-11H2O-2CO2.-2COOH]-, 457.0 [M-5.5H2O]-, 413.0 [M-CO2]-. (It is a Zn monomer consisting of two crystallographically independent molecules in the asymmetric unit.)

[Cd2(Hpimda)2(DMF)2] n  (3)

Complex 3 was synthesized by heating a mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (61.6mg, 0.2mmol), H3pimda (198mg, 0.1mmol), benzidine (18.4mg, 0.1mmol), terephthalic acid (16.6mg, 0.1mmol) in mixed solutions of DMF (3mL) and H2O (3mL) at 75°C for 48h. Colorless block crystals of 3 were obtained. Yield: 56.64mg (74%). The products were washed by distilled water and dried in air. Anal. Calc. for 3: C, 34.61; N, 11.01; H, 3.93. Found: C, 34.92; N, 11.35; H, 3.99%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3435 (s), 2965 (m), 1658 (vs), 1571 (vs), 1474 (vs), 1383 (vs), 1269 (s), 1125 (s), 921 (m), 787 (w), 677 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, DMSO): δ =13.71 (s, 1H, N-H), 4.35 (t, J =5.0Hz, 2H, -CH 2CH2CH3), 3.45 (m, J =5.6Hz, 2H, -CH2CH 2CH3), 1.05 (t, J =7.0Hz, 3H, -CH2CH2CH 3) ppm. ESI-MS: m/z =572.9 [M-2DMF-COOH]-.

cln_elements.content:

cln_elements.clean_text:
Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the architecture of 3 is a two-dimensional network with monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of complex 3 consists of two cadmium ions, two Hpimda2- dianion ligands and two DMF molecules, which is shown in  . The central Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two imidazole rings nitrogen atoms from two single Hpimda2- ligands, one carboxyl oxygen atom from a single Hpimda2- ligand and one oxygen atom from DMF molecule; forming a slightly distorted CdO4N2 octahedron. Bond lengthes of Cd-O vary from 2.265(4) to 2.534(3)Å and the Cd-N distances range from 2.227(3) to 2.283(4)Å, respectively ( ).

Luminescent properties

   presents the absorption and emission data for complexes 1-3 and H3pimda in DMSO solution and in the solid state at room temperature. Three complexes show two main absorption bands, which are similar to H3pimda in the UV region. The electronic absorption spectra of complexes show low energy absorption bands at ca. 334-365nm (340nm for ligand H3pimda), and higher energy absorption bands at ca. 284-301nm (291nm for ligand H3pimda), which can be attributed to ligand-centered π→π∗ transitions .

The luminescent properties of these three metal complexes and H3pimda have been investigated in the solutions of DMSO (). The emission bands of H3pimda are observed at 417, 439 sh  and 466nm under excitation at maximum excitation wavelength of 312nm in solution of DMSO. Complex 1 has blue fluorescent emissions in DMSO solution (concentration: [M]~10-4) at room temperature, with emission bands at 420, 439 sh  and 466nm (415, 439 sh  and 465nm for complex 2; 415, 438 sh , 464nm for 3). For the multiple emission bands of complexes 1-3, the main peaks locate at their expected positions compared with the free ligand. The resemblance of the emission spectra of complexes 1-3 and the free H3pimda ligand in DMSO solution supports that the luminescence emissions of these complexes are due to ligand-centered π∗ →π transitions. The quantum yields of complexes 1-3 and H3pimda in DMSO solution were determined, with the value of H3pimda is 0.022, while that of complexes 1-3 are 0.33, 0.34 and 0.11, respectively. The quantum yields of these complexes are greatly improved compared with free ligand. That because the chelation of H3pimda to the metal center, which increases the rigidity of the ligand H3pimda, and reduces the loss of energy by thermal vibration decay, enhances the ligand-centered π∗ →π fluorescent emission . Furthermore, the quantum yield of the complex 2 is higher than that of complexes 1 and 3, which can be attributed to the heavy atom effect caused by the coordination of the ligand to the heavy Cd(II) center .

Complexes 1-3 have blue-green fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.   shows the excitation and emission spectra of complexes 1-3 as well as the free ligand in the solid state measured at room temperature. The emission bands of complex 1 are located at 404 and 460 sh  nm (408, 467 sh  and 507nm for complex 2, 480nm for 3), which is similar to that of free ligand. The fluorescent emissions of complexes 1-3 can be assigned to the intra-ligand π∗ →π transitions. In addition to the steady-state emission, we also performed time-resolved measurements of complexes 1-3. The luminescence decay curves of complexes 1-3 are measured by the time-correlated single photon counting (TCSPC) technique at room temperature. The decay curves are well fitted into a double-exponential function: I 0 = I + A 1exp(-t/τ 1)+ A 2exp(-t/τ 2), I 0 and I are the luminescent intensities when time t = t and t =0, respectively, whereas τ 1 and τ 2 are defined as the luminescent lifetimes (). The fluorescence decay processes of complexes 1-3 all consist of two components, corresponding lifetimes are τ 1 =1.07μs, τ 2 =7.97μs for 1; τ 1 =1.43μs, τ 2 =9.85μs for 2; τ 1 =1.51μs, τ 2 =9.10μs for 3, respectively ().
